captions.text:
Britain is apparently facing its worst winter
for 100 years with snow falling from as early

as November. Now, if you've got a four-wheel
drive car, you probably think you're properly
prepared - but are you?

We've come to Tamworth Snowdome in the Midlands
to find out if a FWD car with winter tyres

has more traction in the snow than a 4x4 with
summer tyres.

For this, we're using two Ford Kugas - both
have 2.0-litre diesels and both have manual

gearboxes. However the blue one is front-wheel
drive, and the grey one is 4 wheel drive.

Before we do that, we need to see how far
up the slope the FWD car get on summer tyres.

Ok, here we are. FWD car, summer tyres. Don't
think I'm going to be getting far up this
slope, but let's see anyway!

We're not moving any more. That was pretty
useless.

We measured the distance and found it stopped
at 7 metres. Not too surprising.

In cold conditions the rubber in summer tyres
gets harder and less grippy. Winter tyres

use a softer compound. They also have a tread
pattern that's specifically designed to pick

up snow. If you've ever built a snowman you
will know that nothing grips to snow better
than snow itself.

Let's find out if when we fit the FWD car
with winter tyres, it can go further up the

slope than the 4x4 with summer tyres. The
winter tyres we're using are Goodyear UltraGrip
8 Performance, which cost £720 on our car.

Road tester Owen Mildenhall will be helping
out by driving the 4x4 version of the Kuga,

which incidentally casts £1500 more than
the 2WD model.

I'm in the FWD car again, but this time it's
got the winter tyres on it and it's going

to be interesting to see how much further
it gets up the slope and whether it can go

further up there than the 4x4 model on summer
tyres.

OK, so we've got 4 wheel drive, but summer
tyres. Now, a lot of people with 4-wheel drive

think that's all they're going to need so
let's see how we get on. It's a really steep

incline with think snow from a standing start,
so the worst scenario possible.
It's pretty steep...
Off we go. Got some grip.

This time, I got away easily, and driving
in first gear at 2000rpm the FWD Kuga powered

up the slope. Owen on the other hand, was
going nowhere.

Straight away I'm not going any further. It's
dug into the snow.

I'm at the first level and he's just stopped
- he's not doing so well...

Just no traction, even with 4 wheel drive.
Is he sliding back?

That's easy - the second slope, go round this
corner, can I get all the way to the top?
It's tricky...That's it.

Once again we measured the distances - this
time, with winter tyres, the FWD Kuga went

110 metres up the slope. The 4x4 car only
made it 13 metres up, before sliding back

down 9 metres. That means that in the end
it ended up no further than the FWD did with
summer tyres.

For fairness, we should show you what the
4x4 Kuga can do when you have it fitted with
winter tyres.

With summer tyres it really didn't get far
on the slope- maybe 2 car lengths and then

slid back again. It's not permanent 4 wheel
drive so when the front wheels start spinning

by the time the rear wheels come into play
it's already stuck. So now we've got winter
tyres, let's see the difference.

Gently on the clutch, it's an amazing difference.
No wheelspin, loads of grip.

This time, the all-wheel drive Kuga went all
the 136 metres up the ski slope. Obviously,

the best solution for driving on snow is to
have a 4x4 on winter tyres. Without the right

rubber, a 4x4 is just as useless as a 2 wheel
drive car.

This test was all about traction, but the
improved braking winter tyres give you is

actually far more important. Having all wheel
drive won't help with you with that one bit.

In fact if you want to see how much better
your braking is with winter tyres not only

on snow, but also when it's just wet and cold,
click here to watch our video.
And don't forget - make sure you drive safely!

title: Winter Tyres or 4x4: which is best? - Auto Express

comments.text:
Those "winter" tires has no use in scandinavia :/ real winter tires does 
have studs also.﻿
comments.author: Aki Laurila

comments.text:
#1 rule of driving is to drive to the conditions you are in. Warm and dry, 
you can go faster. Cold and wet, go slower.﻿
comments.author: Bob Dobalina

comments.text: Let's settle down the argument of winter VS summer tires.﻿
comments.author: Xiangjun Du

comments.text:
It depends on the car.
 A Land Rover works perfectly on snow even summer tyres. Although ot is 
true that winter tyres are better. Is it possible that those car grip on 
mud as well? In thos case we will not have to buy A/T tyres and listen to 
them on the tarmak﻿
comments.author: gasteratosn

comments.text:
+gasteratosn AWD give you better traction, but not more friction. It "just" 
distributes torque to all 4 corners. Some do a very good job at juggling 
that distribution, too. NO awd solution however, is ever going to help you 
STOP on a slippery surface. That requires more /friction/.
comments.author: pr0xZen

comments.text:
Unless you drive a performace car, why do you ever want to put a summer 
tire anyway? This test should be between all season tires or all terrain 
tires and winter tires﻿
comments.author: Bigtruck Bob

comments.text:
+Bigtruck Bob Grip, balance, rolling resistance, resistance to 
hydroplaning, comfort, fuel echonomy, loglevity... all of them. These are 
not large trucks, most of them don't even put much more than 350-450 kg 
down on each corner.
comments.author: pr0xZen

comments.text: i wish they would of compared winter tired to all season tires﻿
comments.author: ericiscoolllll

comments.text:
Why don't you show all season tires on AWD?!!

So many of these videos put out by tire companies to get you to buy another 
set of tires. Don't listen to them.
I have all wheel drive, all season tires. Can't even get them to slip on 
ice, I've tried.
Please notice all these videos being made by people trying to sell you 
another set of tires.﻿
comments.author: David Imm

comments.text:
Had you shut off the traction control when you started, you would likely 
have made it all the way to the top in the front-wheel drive.  Traction 
control works against you in winter conditions.﻿
comments.author: melinuxfool

comments.text: kuga???? jajajajajajjajaja thats a Escape.﻿
comments.author: José Antonio

comments.text:
Doesn't apply to us American at all. Most of our cars come with all-season 
tires that's designed for wet & snow traction. Our cars are also heavier 
and automatic compares with those in UK.﻿
comments.author: Peichen01

comments.text:
You must not live the part of the country that has real winters....  All 
Season tires are useless in Northern Vermont.  I've lived in Colorado & 
Chicago and those winters are a joke compared to our winters in Northern 
VT,
comments.author: Joe jay

comments.text:
In the UK, in my view, we should make the move to all-season tyres.  Far 
more appropriate for our climate.
comments.author: Rob Lightbody

comments.text: It is so lovely that Matt has the ski board :)﻿
comments.author: Henry Sit

comments.text: I pike studded tires can't go wrong at all﻿
comments.author: Aaron Brown

comments.text:
+Aaron Brown Depending on your typical driving environment. If you only get 
wet ice and "proper snowfall" 3-4 times during winter, studless might make 
more sense. Better fuel economy, and If 85% of the time is on wet-salted 
asphalt, then the stud racket gets tiresome (no pun intended) after a few 
months. If changing shoes a few times a year, you pick a pair that will 
hold up to your intended use.
comments.author: pr0xZen

comments.text:
Disable traction control, you'll climb right on up. 

Also those summer tires are Goodyear Eagle F1 Assymetric 2s, very good Max 
Performance Tires.﻿
comments.author: Brodey Dover

comments.text:
I saw plenty of wheelspin in the video - don't think the slip control in 
the Kuga would allow for such lengthy wheelspin before starting to lock up. 
But nothing is going to help here other than more friction - as its clear 
that on the summer tires they didn't have enough friction to overcome the 
weight of the car on the incline. That means you'll have to go "in" with 
initial built-up speed, and lightly deaccelerate all the way up the hill, 
otherwise you'll break the friction bond with the surface. If that happens, 
your screwed :/
comments.author: pr0xZen

comments.text:
Traction control will prevent you from wheelspin; something that is 
necessary to climb hills in the winter. I regularly pass CUVs in my Abarth 
going up to the ski hill.
comments.author: Brodey Dover

comments.text:
+Brodey Dover Its not really a traction control issue, more a haldex issue. 
The awd is a viscous coupling. Takes a bit of slip time, before it locks 
up. By that time you've lost too much momentum,
comments.author: pr0xZen

comments.text:
Winter tyres or 4x4, which is best 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mfuE00qdhLA﻿
comments.author: David Greenbank

comments.text: Very interesting
comments.author: Marty Fisk

comments.text:
most 'untrained' awd/4wd drivers forget, they might be able to drive 
further or faster by virtue of the extra driven wheels, but they usually 
seem to forget they can't stop any better than anyone else. This year I 
have fitted winter tyres to my Citroen C15 and it's like a different 
vehicle, even driven on sheet ice it still retain a good degree of control. 
It's so much cheaper to invest in a set of cheap wheels and winter tyres 
than go to the expense of a trendy soft roader too!﻿
comments.author: Andy Maddams

comments.text:
+Andy Maddams This. I've been trying to explain this to friends and family, 
but some don't seem to realize it. No manner of propulsion traction, is 
going to help you stop. Ony friction can do that.
comments.author: pr0xZen

comments.text:
Note that. 2wd, 4wd, awd, awd symetrical, are all different systems and 
they all behave differently on snow, ice, water, or road.﻿
comments.author: Subaru STI (Steveuk260)

comments.text:
run winter tyres on my smart fortwo all year round it sticks to the road 
like shit to a blanket.﻿
comments.author: Eric Parton

comments.text:
Those are fairly pathetic winter tires!  The tread pattern looks more like 
all season or weatherhandler tires not winter tires.﻿
comments.author: Stinky Cheese

comments.text:
Winter Rated tires like the Nokian WRG3 winter rated all season tyres make 
all the difference for grip when starting, stopping and turning. This 
example demonstrates this difference even though another brand is being 
used.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mfuE00qdhLA  Nokian tires.com sold 
by ARA of Madison﻿
comments.author: Casey O'Keefe

comments.text:
would be interesting to see how all-season tires would compare here. From 
personal experience, I can make it through the winter season with 
all-season tires, but noticed it sacrifices ~30% braking distance and about 
50% ice grip vs my winter set. Car is a 6spd a4 quattro (so its AWD) driven 
daily in Edmonton, Canada (yes it snows a lot here and gets very very 
cold).﻿
comments.author: Mohammad AlRefai

comments.text:
you got to take in consideration the stopping distance and the control that 
is highly increased with winter tires. Those two aspects are THE most 
important things when driving under snow/ice conditions. personally i dont 
care if i need to go anywhere unless i know i'll be able to stop on time if 
theres a kid crossing the street! ... if I run into heavy traffic or a stop 
light!!! -From a 20 yrs old!﻿
comments.author: justrockon426

comments.text:
yo guys i live in northern canada where we have a 120 inches of snow during 
a 6 month period of winter, it is MANDATORY by law to have snow tires on 
our cars 4 month a year, i dont need a zero to come and help me save the 
day!
comments.author: justrockon426

comments.text:
By no means am I promoting driving any faster or less defensive, than your 
capacity to safely control the vehicle you're currently driving, under the 
circumstances that you you are currently driving. And I believe I've made 
that very clear. But no matter how you turn it, Just because you maintain 
to never have experienced winter slides, does not mean that other 
experienced and careful drivers have not. By your "only thread matters", 
people should expect superior winter tractions with shoe soles carved from 
a block of polished wood, as long as the thread is appropriate. That simply 
is not true. That require the material surface you contact with, to be soft 
enough for tracks to sink in, but firm enough to hold the torque of a 
driving wheel - which is rarely the case during winter time.
comments.author: pr0xZen

comments.text:
+pr0xZen
Having never been in a winter slide scenario and having driven for 3 
decades in slippery snow/etc, I'm going to have to call BS on that logic, 
that it's still just a matter of knowing your vehicle and driving sanely.

Certain winter tires do climb hills better, but beyond that it's just a 
band-aid for idiots.  No matter what tires you have on at a particular 
moment you must drive safe for the condition.

PERIOD.  Don't suggest things within the context of driving as fast as 
possible because that's the person who wrecks, when obviously time was not 
so precious or else the person wouldn't be on youtube at all.
comments.author: Stinky Cheese

comments.text:
+Stinky Cheese You do realize that you have to have decent emergency 
braking performance too? Not all sudden stops can be planned ahead. Doesn't 
matter if you were doing 25 in the 55 - if you come to a stop 50 meters 
after you ran over the kid.
comments.author: pr0xZen

comments.text:
+justrockon426
They did that the last run.  Stopping is just something you accept will 
increase and drive slower, brake sooner.
comments.author: Stinky Cheese

comments.text: now lets see both w/ winter tires 4wd vs. 2wd!
comments.author: justrockon426

comments.text:
This was interesting, but I'd be more interested in the results if you'd 
used all seasons instead of summer tires.  I don't know anybody who uses 
summer tires in this temperate climate.  The default tire is almost 
universally all season, which is going to be better in the winter than 
summer tires (obviously) but not as good as winter tires (also obvious, 
hopefully.)﻿
comments.author: Frank Burns

comments.text: All seasons are still not as good as winter tyres
comments.author: Isobel201

comments.text: Winter tyre video from Auto Express﻿
comments.author: BatteriesOnTheWeb

comments.text:
VAGINA!!!
So, what about winter tyres/tires in Summer? 
Ah ha!﻿
comments.author: emaswat900

comments.text:
+emaswat900 Regarding studless; Not good traction, fast wear due to rubber 
blend vs temperature, very poor wet road performance... Here in Norway they 
are legal during summertime, but not really wise. If inadequate tyre 
performance was deemed the cause of an accident, your insurance company is 
likely to leave you with the bill.
comments.author: pr0xZen

comments.text:
+Frank Burns
BUT, what they used are NOT winter tires.  They are marketing dept. BS.  
Winter tires have more pronounced tread.  All season tires with the 
blockier tread have better performance than their fake winter tires with 
summer tread.
comments.author: Stinky Cheese

comments.text:
+Stinky Cheese All seasons really should be called "three seasons" if you 
live in an areas where the winters are cold and snowy.  You can use them in 
winter and be okay most of the time, but if you're in a hilly area, you'll 
be amazed how much a difference winter tires make in even the slightest 
amount of snow.
comments.author: Frank Burns

comments.text:
+Frank Burns
You wouldn't be sacrificing much traction with that particular set of 
winter tires because they're not very winter like, still put most of the 
tread on the road plus the softer compound.

The better option is all season tires in both summer and winter.  They too 
will obviously wear faster than having a set of both summer and winter 
tires but then you also avoid having to buy another set of tires and wheels 
so you usually come out ahead.

Consider where you drive though, if I had a need to drive up ski slopes 
then that vehicle and either of those tires aren't what I'd be in.
comments.author: Stinky Cheese

comments.text:
They're gonna wear out quicker due to their softer compound, and have worse 
traction.  That's why they're called *winter* tires.
comments.author: Frank Burns

comments.text:
its true your awd car is useless with summer tires in snow.   Last winter i 
was driving my wrx thru colorado in december and there was a huge snow 
storm almost 0 viability.   I was on summer dunlops that came stock on the 
wrx.   the car was useless i could not travel over 30 mph and stopping was 
done with engine braking only cause if i braked the abs would start 
malfunctioning.   That was the worst 250 miles of driving in my entire 
life.   It took me 7 hours to travel 250 miles.   If you live in snowy 
climate just buy an extra set of tires and rims!.      This is not a sales 
gimmick you need winter tires!  ﻿
comments.author: beastsumo

comments.text:
+Stinky Cheese I'd like to see you and your car survive the cold season 
above the polar circle on winter roads. There's a reason why summer tires 
on winter surface is highly illegal here. You might make a mockery of 
studless winter tires, but at the level of performance they've reached now, 
they're pretty much as good as studded on the really nasty bits, and much 
better on the "average winter drive" here. We know, we have 20-30 million 
cars doing 6 months testing every single year.
comments.author: pr0xZen

comments.text:
+Stinky Cheese
LOL and you say "temperature" means nothing??  You talk like a true 
inexperienced dumb ass.  Obviously you've never experienced constant 
subzero temperatures. Just because your temperatures drop to 10F, and you 
get 4" of snow and your "all season" tires work "great", it doesn't mean 
shit.

Try 110"+ of snow a year and temperatures up to -40F excluding the wind 
chill, now that's a real winter.
comments.author: Joe jay

comments.text:
+Gainastyle
I wouldn't say we're all "dumb asses"  I am an American and I stand 100% 
behind winter tires.  I live in a place with 3+ months of harsh winters and 
snow tires make all the difference.  You got all these stupid idiots that 
think it is a marketing gimmick, but those people are fucking clueless.  
They probably live in FL or Arkansas and talk like they're winter driving 
"experts".
comments.author: Joe jay

comments.text:
+Stinky Cheese
You're an idiot.  Your "All season" tires may work great in your pathetic 
winters.  However, they are utterly useless in places with real winters.  
Until you've lived and driven in a place with a real winter, I'd recommend 
you STFU.  Better, yet, why don't you drive up here in Jan-March on your 
magnificent "All Season" tires. LOL  It will be hilarious.

Come up here, drive up a snowy hill on your "all season" tires and we film 
it then put it on youtube.  You'll be the laughing stock lol.
comments.author: Joe jay

comments.text: +Gainastyle we have lowered the bar to core levels.
comments.author: beastsumo

comments.text:
The fact that you american dumbasses even think that winter tyres is a 
sales gimmick shows how stupid you are.
comments.author: Gainastyle

comments.text:
i was yelling at the sky screaming stop snowing 3 hours into my 7 hour 
journey threw a blizzard.    get a set of rims with snow tires.  if i lived 
in a snowy climate i would have a set but i do track days so my extra set 
has summer tires as well.   Tires are 80% of the game no joke.
comments.author: beastsumo

comments.text:
+Joe jay
Hmm, throw away money, get informed by spending more money, then pretend to 
be an expert based on how much money was spent.

Total fail.
It's a shame you still can't grasp the obvious.

Temperature means nothing for snow traction.  It's ALL about tread.

You are a victim of deceitful marketing.   The proof is the money trail, or 
rather, those who have better results without all this nonsense.
comments.author: Stinky Cheese

comments.text:
+Stinky Cheese No, actually the tires are pretty good tires based on 
ratings.  They work fine in late October to mid December, after that 
they're useless.  Trust me, when the highest temperature you have in a 3 
month period is around 20F, the all-season tires harden almost as bad a 
summer tires.  It is -30F outside right now, which is 40 degrees warmer 
than 10F.  Our high today is going to be -4F.

Like I said, All-Season tires are better than summer tires in the winter, 
however, that is mostly true where you have milder winters.   When the 
temperature stays below freezing for months on end and they don't have a 
chance to warm up and regain some of their flexibility, they perform 
poorly.
comments.author: Joe jay

comments.text:
+Joe jay
I'm thinking they sold you the wrong "high-end all-season tires".  It's not 
price, not high-endness that matters.  It's tread pattern.

Stopping in snow is not a big deal at all.  Drive slower.  There is no 
different requirement for a long winter than a short one.  It generally is 
below freezing where it snows, something about water needing to freeze or 
something lol.

Around here it is nothing but hills and snows every winter.  It may not be 
arctic cold but it's about 10F outside right now and I have never needed 
more than all season, ALL TERRAIN tires on my 4wd suv.

If you get all season street tires instead then you're driving on snow 
instead of contact with the street, sure, you shouldn't have gotten street 
tires.

Winter street tires are poor on snow too!
comments.author: Stinky Cheese

comments.text:
+Stinky Cheese I bought a new Subaru Outback in Phoenix last year while 
visiting my brother.  The car came with stock summer tires.  When I brought 
up the fact that I was taking the car back to Northern Vermont with me the 
dealer sold me a set high-end all-season tires to replace the stock summer 
tires.  I was told "It would be the only set of tires I would need"  well, 
let me tell you... that is not the case... Stopping distances suck, going 
up snowy hills sucks.  The "all season" tires do only slightly better than 
summer tires, but fall WAY short than what winter tires can do.  We average 
over 100" of snow a year and unlike other parts of the US, our winters are 
constant.  Once the temperature drops below freezing around late December, 
we don't see a temperature above 32 for the next 4 months...  I own a house 
up a steep road and I could never make it up the road with the "all season" 
tires.  Never have a problem with winter tires.

While "all season" tires may be good in milder winters, don't waste  your $ 
on them if you live where you have harsh long winters.
comments.author: Joe jay

comments.text:
+Gainastyle Believe whatever you like and so will I, having driven a 4WD 
vehicle with all season tires for 16 years of snow without a single 
accident.  Granted, in recent years I only drive it when it snows or need 
to haul something due to a newer vehicle and higher gas prices.
comments.author: Stinky Cheese

comments.text:
Problem is that every so often it gets that cold in areas where all seasons 
are sufficient, and then the accidents happen. Thats why i believe that you 
need real winter tires in every location it snows during the winter.
comments.author: Gainastyle

comments.text:
+Gainastyle
I appreciate that you keep mentioning your location as that is important.  
In many areas it may snow often but doesn't get or stay cold enough for all 
season tires to get overly hard and it's warm enough for salt and other 
road treatments to melt ice and snow.

Perhaps that is the key, that all season tires are popular where its viable 
to use them.
comments.author: Stinky Cheese

comments.text:
+Stinky Cheese Because you said that having two sets of tires, winter and 
summer is not practical or economic. But if you use all season tires in 
norway, you are in big trouble when the winter hits. There isent really 
anything called all season tires, they are just bad summer and winter 
tires, You need real winter tires here, not a compromise.
comments.author: Gainastyle

comments.text:
+Gainastyle
Why are you writing this to me?  I have never suggested using summer tires 
in winter, rather using ALL SEASON tires in winter.  "IF" all season tires 
are sold in  your area then they are legal to use in winter.

However read the rest of what t I wrote more carefully, which is that their 
so called winter tires are meant for cold concrete not snow, have less 
(aggressive) tread than my all season tires which means they "might" stop 
better on ice (or might not), would have better traction on cold concrete 
(but you should simply drive slower in that situation in case you come upon 
black ice)  but will be worse on snow than my all season tires.

In other words for the purposes of the video which is to show the snowy 
hill climbing capabilities, neither of their tires are a good choice.

They forgot something very important, that you not only need traction going 
up a hill but enough traction to stop an uncontrollable slide DOWN a snowy 
hill, and not all road hills go straight and are banked properly.

It is understandable that they didn't want to test that because an 
uncontrolled descent down a hill can easily cause sufficient vehicle 
acceleration to cause a collision, damaging the test vehicles.
comments.author: Stinky Cheese

comments.text:
+Stinky Cheese Use summer tires in Norway in the winter and you would lose 
your license. I dont know what country you are from, where you can drive 
with summer tires on snow legally. You might make it up the hill but you 
wont be able to stop as well as with winter tires at all.
comments.author: Gainastyle

comments.text:
That's not really true, they're making an arbitrary distinction.  My summer 
tires have tread suited for snow more than their winter tires and although 
not as soft a compound, I find the softer compound does little good on 
snow, that it's better for ice... so, it's likely I have better traction 
with my 4WD in winter without having to own or swap in and out winter tires 
twice a year.

So no, you don't really need winter tires.  Get AWD or 4WD and the tread to 
match.  Nobody needs their tight tread pattern for summer tires unless the 
fool drives like a maniac and by that I mean poorly, not just fast on 
straightaways.

Then again if you truly live in a snowy climate then you get tires with 
studs and have to take them off every time you're on clean concrete.  For 
practically purposes that means you have one vehicle dedicated to deeper 
snow in winter and a 2nd one for less snowy conditions, then you store them 
both in the garage when it's time to get out the summer car and motorcycle.

I guess my point is that if you're economizing and trying to make one car 
do everything, then it makes about as much sense to just get one set of 
tires that does everything instead of a summer set and winter set... 
Really, those were not true winter tires just marking for people who live 
where it's flat and hardly ever snows, and their cost was ridiculous.  
Budget all season tires on AWD could handle that hill.
comments.author: Stinky Cheese

comments.text:
try driving a 2011 Nissan 370z through a snow storm. hahaha, it's miserable.

(stock summer tires)
comments.author: Clay Martin

comments.text:
Winter tires on a front wheel drive or summer tires on a 4-wheel drive? 
Which is best? Check out the video to see! http://youtu.be/mfuE00qdhLA﻿
comments.author: Boyds Tire and Auto Service

comments.text:
Drove landrover for 9 years with 4 different brands of #winter ' tyre there 
is no better winter tyre than the Nokian WR D3 (without studs), I took it 
most places people would not dream of 1:3 cobbled slopes with 6" snow.  
Only time I ever got stuck is when it lost ground clearance (about 18" 
uncompressed snow).  2WD with snow tyres is way better than 4WD with summer 
or 'all weather' tyres.  Obviously winter tyres on a good 4WD is the best 
but every time I got home year before last in the landy, the missus did too 
in her Pug 207 with Nokian's on﻿
comments.author: Jon Fenton

comments.text:
Not necessarily, my "all weather" tires have more aggressive tread than 
their "winter tires".  I mean you can't just look at the name of a tire, no 
matter what it's called the tread pattern matters quite a lot in snow  then 
the compound matters more on ice.

What they had was obviously engineered to spend most of its time on cold 
concrete.
comments.author: Stinky Cheese

comments.text:
Purchase 4 goodyear tires or Dunlop and get up to a $160 mail-in rebate 
until December 31, 2014! Call (585)343-7210 for an appointment! ﻿
comments.author: Dan DiLaura

comments.text:
Winter Tyres or 4x4: which is best?  BOTH!

Summer tyres 2 X 0 = 0
.......................4 X 0 = 0

So, a 4X4 will do just as bad with 0 traction on 4 tyres as a front wheel 
drive car will.﻿
comments.author: HunterXray

comments.text:
+pr0xZen
Unfortunately you can't see the forest because of the trees!  Either is 
vastly superior to FWD in snow and ice.  It's a NIGHT AND DAY difference.  
Instead of theories perhaps you should own a few and drive them in ice and 
snow as I have.
comments.author: Stinky Cheese

comments.text:
There are HUGE differences between 4WD and AWD. Its like comparing a dingy 
and a submarine - they both go in water, but thats where the similarities 
stop. There are even massive variations of function within the loose term 
"AWD". A /very/ large portion of modern AWD cars use a viscous coupling / 
haldex for differentials. With these, in practice - there ARE no awd 
without a loss of traction - they're basicly 2WD with AWD "on demand".And 
that "on dhemand" is when signifcant wheelspin is detected. There MUST be a 
difference in rotational speed between the wheels for the coupling to "lock 
up", and that /requires/ wheelspin.

All the things you've written here, makes me believe the "winter tires" 
you've experienced, mst have been of such poor quality that they couldn't 
be legally sold in e.g. Northern Europe or Japan.
comments.author: pr0xZen

comments.text:
+pr0xZen
You're missing the point which is that you're less likely to lose traction 
in the first place with AWD or 4WD so your risk for something going really 
bad is reduced.

In fact even if you lose control or perhaps most importantly then the AWD 
or 4WD will help you regain control, particularly in hilly situations where 
there's no way to stop a slide so you have to drive your way out of it.

I have owned both FWD and 4WD (and driven AWD recently as well.  Using same 
type of tires there is no contest.  Some winters I couldn't even get up my 
driveway with FWD and started sliding sideways back down.  I have never  
had a problem like that with my 4WD vehicle.
comments.author: Stinky Cheese

comments.text:
+Stinky Cheese The downside to these cheaper and more eco-driving-friendly 
AWD solutions, ist that the viscous coupling takes a bit of slip to kick 
in. You'll not be flooring it on summer/all-seasons in snow uphill, then 
you wouldn't get anywhere anyway. So by the time the awd kicks in, you've 
lost too much momentum to regain good traction vs torque output. 

Let me offer up something that might be of more severe importance. Where 
things go really bad, is usually those situations that spring a surprise on 
you. Thats usually not where you fail to go farwards or gain traction 
uphill - but where you fail to make a turn, or even worse, fail to stop. No 
AWD or 4WD is going to help you *stop* on snow or ice.
comments.author: pr0xZen

comments.text:
That's not really the case it's just that the snow density and level of 
incline suggested it.  4WD does in fact offer more snow traction using the 
same tires whether they be summer, all weather, or winter and the 
difference is enough to notice in more moderate inclines.

HOWEVER, let's not forget this is a test of FWD, not just 2WD.  The same 
vehicle with RWD would do worse.
comments.author: Stinky Cheese

comments.text:
Flawed test. There are various type of 4wd system out there & various ways 
of how each type operates. Your choice of 4wd vehicle just so happens to be 
of the weakest type of 4wd system. Should've chosen a 4wd vehicle that 
actually stays 4wd.﻿
comments.author: ricqik

comments.text:
That's true.  As they mentioned in the video, with most "awd" systems, 
power isn't diverted to all wheels until you're already slipping.  In many 
situations, that's too late to get you moving again.  In heavy snow, 
nothing beats full-time 4wd.  Had the opportunity to verify that today in 
some heavy, wet snow.  Similar tires on my 4wd Dodge Ram and awd Lincoln 
MKZ, and while both got me out and back around some hilly/twisty roads, the 
Lincoln took was stuck for awhile at a spot where the truck just tanked 
right through.  Took a lot of backing up and going forward, turning the 
traction control on/off, etc., for the Lincoln to get through.  I left my 
Challenger in the garage ;-)
comments.author: Frank Burns

comments.text:
+sic22l I think you should research subarus awd system before moving that 
statement.
comments.author: ricqik

comments.text:
Most AWD cars on the market (including Subarus) have electronic 
differentials like Escape/Kuga.
comments.author: sic22l

comments.text:
Most of you are just not understanding correctly when saying "use 
all-season". They aren't using "summer" tires, that's just what they are 
using, just referring to the non winter tires as summer.  Because 
all-season is kind of an oxymoron, they are utter shit in winter. If you 
think the skoda yeti comes with ZR rated sport summer only tires, you are 
just stupid. ﻿

If that's true, they should say all season, not summer.  Summer tires are

tires in winter, but still not even close to winter tires.

comments.author: sic22l

comments.text:
This message really needs to get out the UK public, but it won't......

Because we'll always have that old hearsay passed down through generations 
, like "Golf is the most reliable car" and "road tax pays for the roads" 
and "all you need in snow is a 4x4".

Not to mention the govt is never going to make it a requirement to have a 
set winter tyres (like in other countries), because this idea that 4x4 is 
all you need, it keeps the automotive industry ticking over during the 
later months of the year, which pays billions back to the govt in VAT.

Also, common sense dictates that if you have two sets of tyres, they're 
both going to last twice as long, but very few people see that.﻿

comments.text:
Winter tires are not just for snow or ice. Below 7 degrees C, normal tires

comments.author: Walter Black

comments.text:
I really wish you guys would stop posting video's with 4x4 in the title and 
then use AWD cars. There is a fair bit of difference!﻿
comments.author: Scott Porteous

comments.text:
+difflocktwo This can actually get pretty complicated because you could add 
part time 4x4 in there too. I suspect that is what some of them mean by 
4x4. But part time has no differential between the front axle and the rear 
axle. AWD cars do have a differential and that needs to lock as well. Of 
course throw traction control in there and you have a whole nother animal 
with brakes controlling where the torque gets applied.
AWD and 4x4 completely different animals. Our family has no use for cars 
that don't have a part time 4x4 switch for a number of reasons. cost of 
repairs, functionality are just two.  Face it why does anyone need AWD on 
dry pavement? Its just extra resistance in the drive train to bring your 
mpg down. And if it is a viscous unit its expensive and goes bad when you 
need it most.
comments.author: consaka1

comments.text:
+difflocktwo 4x4 means that the wheels are all powered by the engine at all 
times, when you set the car in 4x4 mode. AWD is full time FWD with the back 
wheels only coming into action when the front tyres lose tracktion.

Yes, AWD and 4x4 are two very different things.
comments.author: gullf1sk

comments.text:
+gullf1sk 4x4 means 4 out of 4 wheels driven. Right? AWD 
means All Wheel Drive aka all wheels driven. Right? 4 out of 4 wheels makes 
it ALL wheels. They are not two different things.
comments.author: difflocktwo

comments.text: +difflocktwo AWD and 4X4 are two different things.
comments.author: gullf1sk

comments.text:
4x4 just means that four out of four wheels can be powered but the engine. 
6x4 would be four wheel drive but not AWD. If all the wheels can be driven 
then it is all wheel drive. The car just has a shitty transfer method with 
a lot of delay and no manual override.
comments.author: difflocktwo

comments.text:
+difflocktwo as was said in the video by time the fronts slip and power is 
sent to the rear the car has stopped. In a 4x4 the power is always going to 
all 4 wheels.
comments.author: Scott Porteous

comments.text: Except there isn't a difference when the AWD car has four wheels.
comments.author: difflocktwo

comments.text:
Thank you. you have confirmed what everybody up here in the North already 
know. People saying "well, I've got a great 'ol pick up truck yada yada, 
got em off road tyres, doin just fine" - they dont really know what "doin 
just fine" means. 

You should do a test with 4x4 summer tires vs traction control winter tires

Thank you.﻿
comments.author: takiman1

comments.text: I've been skiing there lol﻿
comments.author: Lloydtheawesome

comments.text: TURN OFF THE TRACTION CONTROL AND TRY IT AGAIN﻿
comments.author: tarqsharq

comments.text:
Tires are very important yes.  I will not argue that.

Turning off traction control can help you get out of these situations on 
occasion as sometimes the TC just gives up and stops your wheels from 
spinning entirely.

Sometimes spinning the wheels in a high slip situation like this is the 
only way to get forward momentum.

Tires are a huge component of the situation.  But these guys seem to give 
up on going forward once the traction light blinks on.  The FWD vehicle 
really should have been able to make it all the way if they just gassed it 
with the winter tires on.

(I had a few drinks when I wrote my initial post)
comments.author: tarqsharq

comments.text:
Traction control does not create traction. All it does is attempt to shift 
torque to the other wheel (Since it has a open differential). Since the 
summer tire has little traction anyway, the other wheel will spin, so 
traction control will them brake that wheel and it is a vicious cycle. With 
the AWD system, it is at best 2WD, with one wheel at each axle spinning. 
Tires are important.
comments.author: Tan N

comments.text: Awd is not the same a 4x4. Joke test.﻿
comments.author: Jacob Gunner

comments.text:
That's not even the worst of it.  They left the traction control on in what 
is obviously a high-slip situation.  You can see the power being shut off 
to the wheels when he tries to spin them...

The concept to achieve the right answer is simple, and we don't need a 
video to understand that: traction (so 4x4) doesn't give you GRIP (which is 
the main thing), but correct tyre set do! ;)﻿
comments.author: Riccardo Corazzari

comments.text:
Winter tires are not cost efficient and not practical for Alberta. We have 
slippery, snowy days and then chinooks afterwards. As a result, our roads 
are mostly dry for 80% of the winter and therefore the soft compound of 
winter tires will wear down quickly. In the past I've gotten 2.5 seasons 
out of a set of winters. My 4x4 Ford truck with all terrain tires has no 
trouble getting around. ﻿
comments.author: HCFX2011

comments.text:
+Desmond Ross That's like saying that seat belts are not worth the money 
because they are rarely needed.  Good winters will last you 4+ season.  I 
have Nokian winters and after 3 season they are still at 75%.  You might be 
able to get going in your truck with all terrain tires, but stopping is a 
different story.  Also Chinooks have not been clearing the snow, just 
melting it into ice.
comments.author: Scott McCullough

comments.text:
Winter tires are not about cost.  They safer and they can save a lot of 
time when roads are bad.  They can also be the determining factor is 
whether of not you're able to reach your destination.  Time is money friend!
comments.author: turnintire

comments.text:
you must be in Calgary, up in Edmonton we dont get those chinooks so the 
snow stays on the roads almost all winter
comments.author: . “Colinator4321”

comments.text:
I live in Alberta too and have not notice any extra wear on my winter 
tires. If you use them in the summer then they will wear out quicker but in 
colder weather, they won't wear very fast. All the winter tires I have used 
are also studded winter tires so they are a slightly harder compound than a 
studless tire like X-ice or blizzaks. But even if they did only last 2.5 
seasons, that would just be the price some people are willing to pay for a 
safer vehicle. The problem with 4x4 is people have tons of traction 
accelerating, its when they have to come to a quick stop or something. more 
than 75% of the vehicles I seen in the ditch upside down are SUV's or 
Truck's that have no problem getting around with there 4x4..... Next time 
we get a big snow fall, drive around in 2wd....see how fun it is. I have a 
4x4 F250 work truck that I drive sometimes with newer BFG all terrains and 
it sucks on ice/snow even in 4x4.. it gets up and goes pretty good but it 
sucks at stopping... If it was my truck it would have winter tires on it.
comments.author: Rick V

comments.text:
Winter tires are not just for snow or ice. Below 7 degrees C, normal tires 
simply lose their gripping ability.

the problem with all these tests is that you are using summer tires, which 
everyone knows are useless on the snow. Most cars sold in countries with a

The M5 stays put during the winter !

4X4 never ever beats a good set of winter tyres. I'm from Finland and we

comments.author: Xiaoang Xing (Herbicider)

comments.text:
Snow tires would still win this comparison. In cold weather two winter 
tires provide more maximum grip than four all-season tires. That doesn't 
mean the AWD A/S combination couldn't cope, but the FWD Winter would still 
be more sure-footed. BTW, they are properly called Winter tires, not Snow 
tires. In winter, snow is not the only issue. Another biggie is cold air 
and cold pavement. Winter tires provide a more grip on cold, dry pavement 
than any 4 season tire.

comments.author: crephotos

comments.text:
So first - It seems like the presenter doesn't know how to start off on 
snow, he just floors it. Second the next presenter FINALLY admits that 
actually the "all wheel drive" Kuga is actually 2 wheel drive and only when 
traction is lost at the front is power transferred to the rear - that's not 
what real 4WD is.  A fairer test (to prove difference between 4x4 & winter 
tyres 2x4) would be say a Subaru XV vs a Ford focus. You could get them on 
extremely similar size wheels etc. Lastly the thundering surprise of the 
day: 4x4 with winter tyres is best. Sherlock Holmes rides again!﻿
comments.author: Shaxston Smith

comments.text:
From Auto car review: "Sharing a platform, many components and a viscous 
coupling-based full-time four-wheel drive system with the Impreza 
hatchback, the XV has a longer wheelbase than the regular hatch as well as 
a more generous ride height." If you look on Subaru website and look at the 
XV technical specs you can see it is AWD all the time, and has a LSD 
viscous coupling, not an ediff.
comments.author: Shaxston Smith

comments.text:
+Shaxston Smith  That was the truth long time ago, but no longer is. 
Especially with CVT transmissions they use the simpliest AWD that can send 
up to 50% of power to the rear wheels. That's worse than Kuga! (which also 
have constant AWD, you can't switch it off) Even Forester has electronic 
diff with electronic locking activated by the switch (X-mode), Fuel 
consumption is worse because Subarus are pretty simple cars these days with 
old style engines. Real permanent AWDs that send power to all wheels all 
the time are very rare, I think only bigger Audis and WRX/STI have them.
comments.author: sic22l

comments.text:
+sic22l you're wrong. XV is permanent all wheel drive. All Subaru's are. 
They use an Lsd centre diff viscous coupling to allow for front and rear 
rotational difference but all wheels are always driven. Simple indicator is 
that fuel economy in Subaru's is worse than '4x4' competitors using 
switchable 2x4. This is why Subaru specifically say AWD not 4x4.
comments.author: Shaxston Smith

comments.text:
Subaru XV is a front wheel drive car with electronic differential just like 
Kuga. Only WRX and STI have old school AWD with mechanical diffs.
comments.author: sic22l

comments.author: Mike Miller

comments.text:
You are absolutely right. That's one thing our local legislators here in 
Québec got right when they made the use of winter tires mandatory. Four 
Goodyear WRTs on my R-class and four studded Nokian Hakka 7s on the Mrs's 
Cross Country (personally, I hate them with a passion, but they were thrown

comments.author: Shaxston Smith

comments.text:
OK, winter tyres are better on snow it is obvious...
what about the performance of summer tyres in wet, rainy, cold (under 5 
degree Celsius) day - is it splash the water better then the winter tyres, 
and what are the levels ofgrip? Because at least half of the winter we have 
just nasty wet days but there is no snow especially on main roads with lot 
of traffic.﻿
comments.author: benzfen

comments.text: +CaptHollister I have no idea what the temperature was...
comments.author: benzfen

comments.text:
+benzfen What was the temperature when those tests conducted ? Magazines 
have long lead times, so to publish in winter they have to write the 
article in the fall. To do that, they often travel to places that have snow 
year-round even though the actual temperature isn't very cold. That's an 
important consideration because every test conducted in cold, winter 
conditions shows the superiority on winter tires for use in winter, 
regardless of road surface.
comments.author: CaptHollister

comments.text:
Well I meet a person, who has tested winter tires is Switzerland and he sad 
that winter tires are better only on Snow in any other conditions are equal 
or better.
Pretty much the same conclusion I sow and in the Auto Build magazine winter 
tires test
comments.author: benzfen

comments.text:
+Biplav Shrestha No. In all these circumstances winter tires are better by 
far than any other type of tire.  As the temperature drops, tires begin to 
harden and lose grip. Winter tires are made from compounds specifically 
developed to remain soft even in properly cold temps. By 5c (not very cold) 
they outperform all other tire types, including so-called four seasons and 
rain tires, in every road condition including dry pavement. The downside is 
that they wear more quickly when the temperature starts rising.
comments.author: CaptHollister

comments.text:
Fifth gear's Tiff Nedell tested that and the winter tyres were WAY better.
Even old winter tires are better than brand new Continentals in cold wet 
conditions.
comments.author: Bruno Danese

comments.text: +benzfen  rain/wet tyres woulc be better for you then
comments.author: Biplav Shrestha

comments.text:
I know that, but if we have relatively hot winter and the temperature are 
about 5-7 degrees Celsius. No snow just rain - does the winter tyres gives 
better results in aquaplaning or the summer tyres will have more reserves 
and allow higher speed!
Because I can adjust the driving style for the longer stoping distance but 
it is hard to predict where you can have aquaplaning.
comments.author: benzfen

comments.text:
Winter tyres are made of softer compound so on lower temp they will stay 
softer and will have more grip than summer tyres as summer tyres are made 
of compound that is hard at lower temp.
